column2: commonly known as simply FC St Pauli
column3: is a German sports club based in the St. Pauli district of Hamburg.

column1: FC St Pauli has a cross-city rivalry with Hamburger SV; the matches between the two are known as the Hamburger Stadtderby or simply Derby. The club also has a more recent rivalry with Hansa Rostock.While the footballers have enjoyed only modest success on the field
column2: the club is widely recognised for its distinctive social culture and has a large popular following as one of the country's "Kult" clubs
column3: which has now developed beyond Germany. FC St. Pauli supporters are strongly identified with their support of left wing politics.

column1: The club began its existence in 1899 as a loose
column2: informal group of football enthusiasts within the Hamburg-St.Pauli Turn-Verein 1862. This group did not play its first match until 1907
column3: when they faced a similar side assembled from the local Aegir swimming club. Officially established on 15 May 1910
column4: the club played as St. Pauli TV in the Kreisliga Groß-Hamburg (Alsterkreis) until 1924
column5: when a separate football side called St. Pauli was formed. The team played as an undistinguished lower-to-mid table side until making their first appearance in 1934 in the top-flight Gauliga Nordmark
column6: 1 of 16 premier level divisions created in the re-organization of German football that took place under the Third Reich. They were immediately relegated
column7: but returned to the top flight in 1936. Relegated again in 1940
column8: St. Pauli re-appeared in the Gauliga Hamburg in 1942
column9: and played there until the end of World War II.

column2: the club resumed play in the Oberliga Nord in 1947. A second-place finish in the 1947–48 season led St. Pauli to its first appearance in the national championship rounds. They advanced as far as the semi-finals
column3: where they were knocked out 2–3 by eventual champions 1. FC Nürnberg. The club continued to play well throughout the early 1950s
column4: but were unable to overtake rivals Hamburger SV
column5: finishing in second place in five of the next seven seasons
column6: and going out in the early rounds in each of their championship-round appearances from 1949 to 1951. In the late 1950s and into the early 1960s
column7: St. Pauli were overtaken by rivals such as Werder Bremen and VfL Osnabrück
column8: but finished fourth a number of times.

column2: the Bundesliga – West Germany's new top-flight professional league – was formed. Hamburger SV
column3: Werder Bremen
column4: and Eintracht Braunschweig joined the new circuit as the top-finishers from the Oberliga Nord
column5: while St. Pauli found themselves in the second-tier Regionalliga Nord.

column1: Nearly a decade-and-a-half of frustration followed. St. Pauli won their division in 1964
column2: but finished bottom of their group in the promotion play-off round. They took their next Regionalliga Nord title in 1966 and
column3: while they performed far better in the play-offs
column4: still failed to advance to the top-flight
column5: losing out to Rot-Weiss Essen on goal difference
column6: having conceded two more goals. Division championships in 1972 and 1973
column8: were each followed by promotion-round play-off disappointment.

column2: and the growth of professional football in West Germany
column3: led to the formation of the 2. Bundesliga in 1974. St. Pauli was part of the new second-tier professional circuit in the 2. Bundesliga Nord and in 1977
column4: they finally advanced to the top flight as winners of their division. The team survived just one season at the highest level in the Bundesliga.

column1: The club's return to the 2. Bundesliga Nord was also short-lived. On the verge on bankruptcy in 1979
column2: they were denied a license for the following season and were sent down to the Oberliga Nord (III). Strong performances that set the team atop that division in 1981 and 1983 were marred by poor financial health. By 1984
column3: the club had recovered sufficiently to return to the 2. Bundesliga
column4: overtaking Werder Bremen's amateur side who
column5: despite finishing two points ahead of St. Pauli
column6: were ineligible for promotion.

column1: It was in the mid-1980s that St. Pauli's transition from a standard traditional club into a "Kult" club began. The club was also able to turn the location of its ground in the dock area part of town
column2: near Hamburg's famous Reeperbahn – centre of the city's night life and its red-light district – to its advantage. An alternative fan scene slowly emerged
column3: built around left-leaning politics
column4: social activism and the event and party atmosphere of the club's matches. Supporters adopted the skull and crossbones as their own unofficial emblem. St. Pauli became the first team in Germany to officially ban right-wing nationalist activities and displays in its stadium in an era when fascist-inspired football hooliganism threatened the game across Europe. In 1981
column5: the team was averaging small crowds of only 1
column6: 600 spectators
column7: but by the late 1990s they were frequently selling out their entire 20
column8: 000-capacity ground.The skull and crossbones symbol had always been associated with St Pauli (the city quarter) in one way or another. Hamburg fostered the most famous pirate of Germany
column10: and the symbol had been used by the 1980s squatters at Hafenstraße. However
column11: the one who should be credited with finally bringing the symbol to the terraces is probably Doc Mabuse
column12: the singer of a Hamburg punk band. As the legend tells
column13: he first grabbed the flag from a stall while passing drunk through the Dom on his way to the Millerntor-Stadion.In the early 1990s
column14: the media in Germany began to recognize the Kult-image of the club
column15: focusing on the punk part of the fan-base in TV broadcasts of the matches. By this time
column16: the media also started to establish nicknames like "Freibeuter der Liga" ("Buccaneers of the League") as well as the satirical "das Freudenhaus der Liga" ("Brothel of the League"

column1: St. Pauli moved in and out of the Bundesliga over the course of the next dozen years: the club was narrowly relegated to the Oberliga in the 1984–85 season
column2: but won the 1985–86 championship and returned to 2. Bundesliga. Two increasingly strong years followed
column3: resulting in promotion and three seasons in the Bundesliga
column4: from 1988 to 1991. Four seasons followed in 2. Bundesliga
column5: and then another two in the Bundesliga In 1995 to 1997
column6: before another return to the 2. Bundesliga.

column2: the club's most recent appearance in the top-flight had been a single-season cameo in 2001–02. A win against Bayern Munich
column3: the reigning Intercontinental Cup winners
column4: led to the popular "Weltpokalsiegerbesieger" ("World Club Champion beaters") shirts. However
column5: the team finished last in the league
column6: partly because the management did not trust the team which surprisingly won the promotion in 2001
column7: but rather spent the additional money from Bundesliga TV contracts and advertisements on expensive but disappointing players. After the relegation to the 2. Bundesliga
column8: only a skeleton of the successful 2001 team remained. The 2002–03 season ended up in chaos
column9: with the team fighting relegation (ultimately in vain) from the very beginning
column10: various coaches departing and other problems internal to the club.

column1: With the club almost bankrupt again and the less-lucrative Regionaliga Nord (III) looming
column2: the club began its fund-raising activities
column3: the so-called "Retteraktion". They printed t-shirts with the club's crest surrounded by the word Retter ("rescuer/saviour") and more than 140
column4: 000 were sold within six weeks. They also organized a lucrative benefit game
column5: against Bayern Munich
column6: to raise funds to save the club.

column1: The club has also been active in terms of charity and in 2005 the club
column2: the team and the fans initiated the Viva con Agua de Sankt Pauli campaign
column3: which collects money for water-dispensers for schools in Cuba
column4: for clean water in Rwanda et cetera.

column2: the team enjoyed unprecedented success in the DFB-Pokal

column5: significantly

column9: and their subsequent place in the DFB Cup semi-final
column10: netted the club approximately €1 million in TV and sponsorship money
column11: going a long way to saving the club from immediate financial ruin.

column1: St. Pauli finally went out of the cup to Bayern Munich on 12 April
column2: going down 3–0 with a goal from Owen Hargreaves and two from Claudio Pizarro. Coincidentally
column3: Bayern were also St. Pauli's opponents and dispatchers in the first round of the following season's cup.

column2: the team was promoted to the 2. Bundesliga. After defeating SpVgg Greuther Fürth in the 2009–10 season
column3: the team secured promotion back to the Bundesliga for the 2010–11 season. On 16 February 2011
column4: during the 2010–11 season and for the first time since 1977
column5: St Pauli defeated their bitter cross-city rivals Hamburger SV away at the Volksparkstadion courtesy of a Gerald Asamoah goal. The team
column6: however
column7: finished the domestic season in last place
column8: resulting in their relegation to the 2. Bundesliga for the 2011–12 season. Since then
column9: the club has remained in the 2. Bundesliga
column10: finishing fourth in 2011–12 but declining in results since then.

column1: St. Pauli enjoys a certain fame for the left-leaning character of its supporters: most of the team's fans regard themselves as anti-racist
column2: anti-fascist
column3: anti-homophobic and anti-sexist
column4: and this has on occasion brought them into conflict with neo-Nazis and hooligans at away games. The organization has adopted an outspoken stance against racism
column5: fascism
column6: sexism
column7: and homophobia and has embodied this position in its constitution. Team supporters traditionally participate in demonstrations in the Hamburg district of St. Pauli
column8: including those over squatting or low-income housing
column9: such as the Hafenstraße and Bambule. The centre of fan activity is the Fanladen St. Pauli.

column1: St. Pauli fans have a strong relationship with the fans of Ternana
column2: Rayo Vallecano
column3: SV Babelsberg 03
column4: Partizan Minsk
column5: Hapoel Tel Aviv
column6: AEK Athens (Original 21) and Celtic. In the past they also had a friendship with the fans of Bohemians 1905. The group Ultrá Sankt Pauli also has a special friendship with the group Schickeria München
column7: from the ultras scene of Bayern Munich. A banner of the Schickeria München is occasionally displayed at the Millerntor Stadion
column8: and a flag of the Ultrá Sankt Pauli – sporting a picture of Che Guevara – has been displayed at the Allianz Arena. Both Ultrá Sankt Pauli and Schickeria München are members of Alerta Network
column9: an international anti-fascist network of supporter groups.

column1: The club prides itself on having the largest number of female fans in all of German football. In 2002
column2: advertisements for the men's magazine Maxim were removed from the Millerntor-Stadion in response to fans' protests over the adverts' sexist depictions of women. In 2011
column3: the club banned lap dancers from performing during match before guests at a corporate suite
column4: following fans' complaints. The suite belonged to local lap dance club Susies Show Bar.St. Pauli is also a worldwide symbol for punk and related subcultures. The skull and crossbones logo and the team's brown and white football jerseys have often been worn by international artists such as the bands Asian Dub Foundation
column5: Gaslight Anthem and Panteon Rococo. The KMFDM frontman and Hamburg native Sascha Konietzko is a recognisable St. Pauli fan
column6: at one point placing a huge picture of a fist smashing a swastika on his band's main page
column7: with the caption "St. Pauli Fans gegen Rechts!" ("St. Pauli fans against the Right") underneath it. American punk band Anti-Flag can be seen wearing St. Pauli shirts in numerous music videos for their album American Fall. Another notable supporter and sponsor is Andrew Eldritch
column8: lead singer of band The Sisters of Mercy. On his 2006 "Sisters Bite The Silver Bullet"- tour

column10: the bassist of the Icelandic post rock band Sigur Rós
column11: has performed at several festivals wearing a St. Pauli T-shirt. Alex Rosamilia
column12: the guitarist for The Gaslight Anthem
column13: frequently wears a St. Pauli hat and hoodie and displays a flag of the club's logo in front of the speakers of his guitar amp. Editors guitarist and synthesiser player Chris Urbanowicz frequently wears the skull and crossbones t-shirt. Dave Doughman
column16: who has been spotted in concert with the skull and crossbones on his guitar and amplifier
column17: moved to St. Pauli in 2010. Bad Religion played a charity match against St. Pauli's third team in 2000. German musicians that are fans include: Fettes Brot

column1: Several bands have also made music directly related to St. Pauli: The Norwegian punk rock band Turbonegro recorded a special version of their song "I Got Erection" with re-worked German lyrics for St. Pauli. In 2009

column3: Venice
column4: wrote the song "St Pauli". The team has since used the song as an anthem and Talco has played a number of concerts at Millerntor-Stadion. Glasgow band The Wakes have also played the Millerntor
column5: having written "The Pirates of the League" about the club. Also
column6: British band Art Brut has written a song about the club called "St Pauli" which is featured on their album It's a Bit Complicated. In 2010
column7: FC St. Pauli celebrated its 100th anniversary. For the occasion
column8: the fan club 18auf12 recorded the song "Happy Birthday St.Pauli
column10: with words and music by Henning Knorr and Christoph Brüx.The Canadian punk rock band The Pagans of Northumberland recorded a song in 2014 called simply "St Pauli" for their first 7-inch detailing their love of the club and its supporters around the world.

column2: FC St. Pauli announced an extensive co-operation with Irish-American Celtic punk band Dropkick Murphys. The co-operation includes a strictly limited seven-inch picture disc of the song "You’ll Never Walk Alone" recorded by the band
column3: and new club merchandise labeled "You’ll Never Walk Alone"
column4: sporting both the club and the band.When the team played in Germany's 2nd Bundesliga
column5: their home fixtures at the Millerntor used to average greater attendances than any other team and often exceeded turnouts for second division teams. As of the 2011–12 season
column6: St. Pauli is the only team that has close to 100% in average home attendance.

column2: St. Pauli had more season ticket holders than many Bundesliga teams. One study estimated that the team has roughly 11 million fans throughout Germany
column3: making the club one of the most widely recognised German sides. The number of official fan clubs in 2011 passed 500 which is an increase of 300 over three years.In January 2020
column4: the club's famous skull and crossbones flag was listed by the United Kingdom's counter-terrorism police in a guide sent to public sector workers
column5: to notice potential extremism
column6: prompting a backlash from St Pauli defender James Lawrence.

column1: St. Pauli were the first club in Germany to integrate a set of Fundamental Principles (Leitlinien) to dictate how the club is run. The Fundamental Principles were passed by an overwhelming majority at the St. Pauli Congress in 2009 and they go beyond solely football.
The first five Principles states that:

column2: consisting of members
column3: staff
column4: fans and honorary officers
column5: St. Pauli FC is a part of the society by which it is surrounded and so is affected both directly and indirectly by social changes in the political
column6: cultural and social spheres."

column1: – "St. Pauli FC is conscious of the social responsibility this implies
column2: and represents the interests of its members
column3: staff
column4: fans and honorary officers in matters not just restricted to the sphere of sport."

column1: – "St. Pauli FC is the club of a particular city district
column2: and it is to this that it owes its identity. This gives it a social and political responsibility in relation to the district and the people who live there."

column1: – "St. Pauli FC aims to put across a certain feeling for life and symbolises sporting authenticity. This makes it possible for people to identify with the club independently of any sporting successes it may achieve. Essential features of the club that encourage this sense of identification are to be honoured
column2: promoted and preserved."

column1: – "Tolerance and respect in mutual human relations are important pillars of the St. Pauli philosophy."
The home venue of the FC St Pauli is the Millerntor-Stadion. Work on the stadium began in 1961
column2: but its completion was delayed until 1963 as there was initially no drainage system in place
column3: making the pitch unplayable after rain. It originally held 32
column4: 000 supporters
column5: but the capacity was later reduced for safety reasons.

column2: the stadium was renamed the Wilhelm Koch-Stadium in honour of a former club president. However
column3: this name became highly controversial when it was discovered that Wilhelm Koch had been a member of the Nazi Party during the war. After protests by fans
column4: the name was changed back to Millerntor-Stadion in 1999.

column1: A total redevelopment began in 2006. The final phase of the redevelopment work ended with the completion of the new north stand in July 2015. The stadium is since then permitted for a capacity of 29
column2: 546 spectators of which 16
column3: 940 are standing and 12
column4: 606 are seated.The stadium is located next to the Heiligengeistfeld
column5: and is overlooked by the infamous Flak Tower IV to the north and a building of the Deutsche Telekom to the south. It can easily be reached with the Hamburg U-Bahn line U3 (St. Pauli Station and Feldstrasse Station).
